on the ''New York Times'' list.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/21/books/bestseller/21besthardfiction.html?gwh=719E75B77658E7FAD694274536E77977 |title=Hardcover Fiction: October 21, 2001 |date=October 21, 2001 |website=NYTimes.com (Internet Archive) |publisher=''The New York Times'' |archivedate=November 27, 2013 |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131127223728/http://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/21/books/bestseller/21besthardfiction.html?gwh=719E75B77658E7FAD694274536E77977 }} ==''Legends of Dune''== '''''Legends of Dune''''' is a [[prequel]] [[trilogy]] of novels written by [[Brian Herbert]] and [[Kevin J. Anderson]], set in [[Frank Herbert]]'s [[Dune (franchise)|''Dune'' universe]]. The series takes place over 10,000 years before the events of the 1965 novel ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'', and chronicles the universe-spanning war against [[thinking machines (Dune)|thinking machines]] that would eventually become known as the [[Butlerian Jihad]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sfcrowsnest.com/articles/books/2009/Dune-The-Butlerian-Jihad-by-Brian-Herber--Kevin-J-Anderson--13987.php |title=Review: ''Dune: The Butlerian Jihad'' by Brian Herbert & Kevin J. Anderson |last=MacDonald |first=Rod |date=January 6, 2009 |website=SFCrowsnest.com (Internet Archive) |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |archivedate=June 15, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615190055/http://www.sfcrowsnest.com/articles/books/2009/Dune-The-Butlerian-Jihad-by-Brian-Herber--Kevin-J-Anderson--13987.php }} It also explores the origins of the families and organizations that populate the distinctive universe in other ''Dune'' works. The books in the series are: * ''[[Dune: The Butlerian Jihad|The Butlerian Jihad]]'' (2002) * ''[[Dune: The Machine Crusade|The Machine Crusade]]'' (2003) * ''[[Dune: The Battle of Corrin|The Battle of Corrin]]'' (2004) ===Plot=== The series explains that after our own time, humanity had become entirely complacent and dependent upon thinking machines; recognizing this weakness, a group of ambitious, militant humans calling themselves the [[Titan (Dune)|Titans]] use this widespread reliance on machine intelligence to seize control of the entire universe. The Titans soon make the transition into [[cyborg]]s called [[cymek]]s; through the use of specialized interfaces, their brains are installed inside giant, mobile, mechanized "bodies." These fearsome, weaponized bodies make the Titans virtually immortal {{mdash}} and invincible. Their rule lasts for a century. Then, having mistakenly given one attendant [[artificial intelligence]] program too much autonomy, the Titans suddenly find themselves overthrown and enslaved by an AI consciousness calling itself [[Omnius]] that seizes control of the entire universe though the interconnected machine network. For over 900 years the Titans live in perpetual servitude to Omnius, cruelly subjugating humanity, quelling human insurrections and secretly plotting their own return to power. At the time of the ''Legends of Dune'' series, over 500 planets {{mdash}} called the '''Synchronized Worlds''' {{mdash}} are under complete machine control, their former human populations either enslaved or killed. The relatively few planets of remaining free humans are united under the '''League of Nobles''', a government using what resources it has to defend the League Worlds against machine aggression. A prominent figure in the human rebellion is [[Serena Butler]], the charismatic daughter of the League Viceroy; the murder of her young son at the hands of the independent robot [[Erasmus (Dune)|Erasmus]] finally incites the Butlerian Jihad, with humanity mounting a decisive offense against machine rule. This crusade against the machines lasts for nearly a century, with much loss of human life but ending in human victory at the [[Battle of Corrin]]. The Jihad also gives rise to the [[Bene Gesserit]], the [[Spacing Guild]], the [[Sardaukar]] army, the [[Landsraad]], and [[House Corrino]], whose [[Padishah Emperor]]s rule the universe for the next 10,000 years, until the events of ''Dune'' and the accession of [[Paul Atreides]].{{cite serial |last=Herbert|first=Brian |author2=Kevin J. Anderson |title=[[Legends of Dune]] |date=2002–2004 }} ===Reception=== ''Dune: The Butlerian Jihad'' rose to #7 on [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''The New York Times'' Best Seller list]] in its second week of publication.{{cite web|title=BEST SELLERS: October 13, 2002 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/10/13/books/best-sellers-october-13-2002.html?gwh=BE1451A02B4094F7586F7EA8D31AE0DA |publisher=''The New York Times'' |website=NYTimes.com (Internet Archive) |date=October 13, 2002 |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |archivedate=November 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131127234900/http://www.nytimes.com/2002/10/13/books/best-sellers-october-13-2002.html?gwh=BE1451A02B4094F7586F7EA8D31AE0DA }} ''Dune: The Machine Crusade'' debuted at #7 on the list.{{cite web|title=BEST SELLERS: October 5, 2003 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/05/books/best-sellers-october-5-2003.html |publisher=''The New York Times'' |website=NYTimes.com (Internet Archive) |date=October 5, 2003 |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |archivedate=May 25, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130525092425/http://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/05/books/best-sellers-october-5-2003.html }} The third installment, ''Dune: The Battle of Corrin'', reached #9 on the New York Times list.{{cite web|title=Hardcover Fiction: September 12, 2004 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/12/books/bestseller/0912besthardfiction.html?pagewanted=print&position=&_r=3& |publisher=''The New York Times'' |website=NYTimes.com (Internet Archive) |date=September 12, 2004 |accessdate=November 28, 2013 |archivedate=November 28, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131128000437/http://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/12/books/bestseller/0912besthardfiction.html?pagewanted=print&position=&_r=3& }} ==''Heroes of Dune''== '''''Heroes of Dune''''' is a planned [[tetralogy]] of novels by [[Brian Herbert]] and [[Kevin J. Anderson]] set in the [[Dune (franchise)|''Dune'' universe]] created by [[Frank Herbert]]. The potential series was initially referred to as ''Paul of Dune'' by the authors as early as 2004.{{cite web|first=Kevin J. |last=Anderson |url=http://dunenovels.com/dune7blog/page95.html |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |title=''Dune 7'' blog |publisher=DuneNovels.com |date=August 5, 2006 |archivedate=October 12, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012125813/http://dunenovels.com/dune7blog/page95.html }}{{cite web |url=http://arrakis.ru/ha_int_mf.shtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050119224924/http://arrakis.ru/ha_int_mf.shtml |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2005-01-19 |title=Interview with Brian Herbert and Kevin J. Anderson |publisher=Arrakis.ru |work=Mir Fantastiki |date=2004 |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |quote=Half of the story is set in the Jihad between ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'' and ''[[Dune Messiah]]'', when [[Princess Irulan]] decides to become [[Paul Atreides|Paul]]'s official biographer, and she will tell the other half of the story, chronicling Paul's younger years (between ''[[Dune: House Corrino|House Corrino]]'' and ''Dune'') |df= }} These novels were intended to "fill in the story" between Frank Herbert's early ''Dune'' novels. The books in the series are: * ''[[Paul of Dune]]'' (2008) * ''[[The Winds of Dune]]'' (2009) Half of the story of ''Paul of Dune'' takes place between Frank Herbert's ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'' (1965) and ''[[Dune Messiah]]'' (1969) as [[Paul Atreides|Paul]]'s Jihad rages, [[Shaddam IV|Shaddam]] seeks to regain his throne and [[Princess Irulan]] accepts the "task of building the legend of Muad'Dib". She in turn chronicles Paul's early years (between the 2001 Brian Herbert/Anderson [[prequel]] ''[[Dune: House Corrino]]'' and ''Dune''), which feature "his friendship with [[Duncan Idaho|Duncan]] and [[Gurney Halleck|Gurney]] and [[Leto I Atreides|Duke Leto]]'s [[War of Assassins]] against [[Grumman (Dune)|Grumman]]".{{cite web|last=Ascher |first=Ian |date=2004 |url=http://www.digitalwebbing.com/interviews/042104_anderson.html |title=Kevin J. Anderson Interview |publisher=DigitalWebbing.com |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |archivedate=July 3, 2007 |quote=[The series] fills the gap between''House Corrino'' and ''Dune'': in other words, the younger years of Paul Atreides and his friendships with [[Duncan Idaho]] and [[Gurney Halleck]] interwoven with the story of Paul's Jihad, which fits between ''Dune'' and ''Dune Messiah''. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703213605/http://www.digitalwebbing.com/interviews/042104_anderson.html }}{{cite web|last=Adams |first=John Joseph |url=http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/index.php?category=5&id=37444 |date=August 9, 2006 |archivedate=February 24, 2009 |title=New ''Dune'' Books Resume Story |publisher=[[SciFi.com]] |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |quote=[The series will] tell the story of Paul's younger years, his friendship with Duncan and Gurney and Duke Leto's War of Assassins against Grumman ... And it will also fill in the story between ''Dune'' and ''Dune Messiah'', Paul's great Jihad, Princess Irulan's task of building the legend of Muad'Dib, Shaddam's bid for a return to power... |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224104054/http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/index.php?category=5&id=37444 }}{{cite web|title=''Paul of Dune'' |publisher=DuneNovels.com |accessdate=November 28, 2013 |url=http://www.dunenovels.com/books/paul.html |archivedate=August 22, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822064047/http://www.dunenovels.com/books/paul.html }} ''The Winds of Dune'' (originally announced as ''Jessica of Dune''){{cite web|first=Kevin J. |last=Anderson |accessdate=November 28, 2013 |title=''Sandworms of Dune'' blog |publisher=DuneNovels.com |date=March 23, 2007 |url=http://www.dunenovels.com/wormsblog/page007.html |archivedate=October 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071029044350/http://www.dunenovels.com/wormsblog/page007.html }}{{cite web|first=Kevin J. |last=Anderson |accessdate=November 28, 2013 |title=''Dune'' blog |publisher=DuneNovels.com |date=April 14, 2008 |url=http://www.dunenovels.com/blog/page033.html |archivedate=June 20, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080620185036/http://www.dunenovels.com/blog/page033.html }} chronicles events between Frank Herbert's ''Dune Messiah'' (1969) and ''[[Children of Dune]]'' (1976).{{cite web|first=Kevin J. |last=Anderson |url=http://www.dunenovels.com/articles/tags-blog/chronology |title=''Dune'' blog: Official Story Chronology |publisher=DuneNovels.com |date=November 29, 2009 |accessdate=November 28, 2013 |archivedate=November 28, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131128183340/http://www.dunenovels.com/articles/tags-blog/chronology }} The final two novels in the series were to be called ''The Throne of Dune'' (formerly ''Irulan of Dune'') and ''Leto of Dune'' (perhaps ''The Golden Path of Dune''). However, in a July 2010 blog post Anderson announced that these novels had been postponed due to plans by Herbert and Anderson to publish a [[trilogy]] (later known as ''[[#Great Schools of Dune|Great Schools of Dune]]'') about "the formation of the [[Bene Gesserit]], the [[Mentat]]s, the [[Suk Doctor]]s, the [[Spacing Guild]] and the [[Guild Navigator|Navigators]], as well as the solidifying of the [[House Corrino|Corrino]] imperium."{{cite web|first=Kevin J. |last=Anderson |url=http://www.dunenovels.com/articles/brainstorming-sisterhood-dune |archivedate=May 18, 2011 |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |title=Brainstorming ''THE SISTERHOOD OF DUNE'' |publisher=DuneNovels.com |date=July 15, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110518041200/http://www.dunenovels.com/articles/brainstorming-sisterhood-dune }} ===Plot=== In ''Paul of Dune'', Paul Atreides's childhood lessons in the political intrigues of the empire are juxtaposed with his current struggle to secure his control over it. His [[Fremen]] armies are spread across the universe in attempt to bring rebel worlds to heel, and Paul avoids one assassination attempt only to nearly die in another.{{cite book |last=Herbert|first=Brian |author2=Kevin J. Anderson |title=[[Paul of Dune]] |date=2008}} In ''The Winds of Dune'', Paul's disappearance into the desert has left a [[power vacuum]], and his closest advisors struggle to determine what path his empire should take.{{cite book |last=Herbert|first=Brian |author2=Kevin J. Anderson |title=[[The Winds of Dune]] |date=2009}} ===Reception=== ''The Winds of Dune'' rose to #15 on [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''The New York Times'' Best Seller list]] in its second week of publication.{{cite web|title=Best Sellers: Hardcover Fiction |url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2009-08-23/hardcover-fiction/list.html |work=The New York Times'' |date=August 23, 2009 |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |archivedate=November 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131127233706/http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2009-08-23/hardcover-fiction/list.html }} ==''Great Schools of Dune''== '''''Great Schools of Dune''''' is a [[prequel]] [[trilogy]] of novels written by [[Brian Herbert]] and [[Kevin J. Anderson]], set in [[Frank Herbert]]'s [[Dune (franchise)|''Dune'' universe]]. A sequel to the ''[[#Legends of Dune|Legends of Dune]]'' trilogy (2002-2004), the series takes place nearly a century after the events of Brian Herbert and Anderson's ''[[Dune: The Battle of Corrin]]'' (2004), in which the Army of Humanity finally defeats the [[Thinking machines (Dune)|thinking machine]] armies of [[Omnius]]. Now, the fledgling [[Bene Gesserit]], [[Mentat]] and [[Suk School]]s, as well as the [[Spacing Guild]], are threatened by the independent anti-technology forces gaining power in the aftermath of the [[Butlerian Jihad]].{{cite web|last=Searle|first=Brenda|title=Review: ''Sisterhood of Dune''|url=http://www.portlandbookreview.com/sisterhood-of-dune/|publisher=Portland Book Review |accessdate=November 21, 2013|date=August 1, 2012}}{{cite web|title=Official site:''Sisterhood of Dune'' |url=http://www.dunenovels.com/novel/sisterhood-dune |website=DuneNovels.com (Internet Archive) |archivedate=November 13, 2013 |accessdate=November 21, 2013 |date=January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113221237/http://www.dunenovels.com/novel/sisterhood-dune }} The ''Great Schools of Dune'' trilogy, first discussed by Anderson in a 2009 interview and later named by him in a 2010 blog post, chronicles the early years of these organizations, which figure prominently in the original ''Dune'' novels.{{cite web|last=Neuman |first=Clayton |date=August 17, 2009 |url=http://blogs.amctv.com/scifi-scanner/2009/08/brian-herbert-interview.php |title=''Winds of Dune'' Author Brian Herbert on Flipping the Myth of Jihad |website=AMCtv.com (Internet Archive) |accessdate=March 31, 2014 |quote=But we think there are perhaps three more ''Dune'' novels after ''Heroes''. We may go on to the founding of the great schools: Dad says there are five, but we're going to do it in three. You've got the Bene Gesserit -- that would be ''The Sisterhood of Dune''; then there's ''The Mentats of Dune'' and ''The Swordmasters of Dune''. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090921011119/http://blogs.amctv.com/scifi-scanner/2009/08/brian-herbert-interview.php |archivedate=September 21, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.mediamikes.com/2013/03/kevin-j-anderson-talks-about-books-hellhole-awakening-mentats-of-dune-and-working-with-rushs-neil-peart-on-clockwork-angels/ |title=Kevin J. Anderson talks about books ''Hellhole Awakening'', ''Mentats of Dune'' and working with Rush’s Neil Peart on ''Clockwork Angels'' |first=Mike |last=Gencarelli |website=MediaMikes.com |date=March 27, 2013 |accessdate=November 27, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://kjablog.com/?p=4946 |title=''MENTATS OF DUNE'' final cover and jacket text |date=November 15, 2013 |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |archivedate=November 27, 2013 |website=KJAblog.com (Internet Archive) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131127183839/http://kjablog.com/?p=4946 }}{{cite web |url=http://amazingstoriesmag.com/2013/01/a-conversation-with-kevin-j-anderson/ |title=A Conversation with Kevin J. Anderson |work=[[Amazing Stories]] |first=Adam |last=Gaffen |date=January 22, 2013 |accessdate=June 5, 2015}} Though the third and final novel was originally identified by Anderson as ''The Swordmasters of Dune'' in 2009, in 2014 Brian Herbert and Anderson confirmed that its title would be ''Navigators of Dune''.{{cite web |url=http://www.flickeringmyth.com/2014/04/interview-brian-herbert-and-kevin-j-anderson-on-dune.html |title=Interview: Brian Herbert and Kevin J. Anderson on ''Dune'' |date=April 9, 2014 |accessdate=June 30, 2014 |website=FlickeringMyth.com}}{{cite web |url=http://kjablog.com/off-the-radar/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141208095457/http://kjablog.com/off-the-radar/ |title=Off the Radar |publisher=KJAblog.com |first=Kevin J. |last=Anderson |date=November 22, 2014 |archivedate=December 8, 2014 |accessdate=January 15, 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://kjablog.com/brainstorming-navigators-of-dune/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209004929/http://kjablog.com/brainstorming-navigators-of-dune/ |title=Brainstorming ''NAVIGATORS OF DUNE'' |publisher=KJAblog.com |first=Kevin J. |last=Anderson |date=November 25, 2014 |archivedate=December 9, 2014 |accessdate=January 17, 2015}} On July 27, 2015, Anderson previewed the cover of ''Navigators of Dune'' on [[Twitter]] and noted its 2016 release.{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/TheKJA/status/625822136850984960 |title=Sneak preview of NAVIGATORS OF DUNE! |first=Kevin J. |last=Anderson |publisher=[[Twitter]] |date=July 27, 2015 |accessdate=August 26, 2015}} The books in the series are: * ''[[Sisterhood of Dune]]'' (2012) * ''[[Mentats of Dune]]'' (2014) * ''[[Navigators of Dune]]'' (2016) ===Plot=== In ''Sisterhood of Dune'', the anti-technology Butlerian movement is gaining momentum under the leadership of the popular Manford Torondo. He and his forces are scouring the universe to cleanse humanity of its reliance on convenient technologies, destroying any machinery they can find. Torondo's growing power threatens the [[House Corrino|Corrino]] Emperor Salvador, as well as the Sisterhood on [[Rossak]] and the Mentat School on [[Lampadas]], each of which harbors secret technology. Space travel tycoon Josef Venport also plots to salvage machinery which he believes can be useful in his business empire.{{cite book |last=Herbert|first=Brian |author2=Kevin J. Anderson |title=[[Sisterhood of Dune]] |date=2012}} ''Mentats of Dune'' finds [[Gilbertus Albans]] carefully managing his Mentat School under the watchful eye of the fanatical Butlerians, while [[Raquella Berto-Anirul]] seeks to rebuild her own Sisterhood School on [[Wallach IX]]. To secure his control of interstellar commerce and strike a blow against the Butlerians, Venport places a trade embargo on any planet which embraces Torondo's movement. ===Reception=== ''Sisterhood of Dune'' debuted at #23 on ''[[The New York Times]]'' Hardcover Fiction [[The New York Times Best Seller list|Best-Seller List]],{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D06E7D9123EF931A15752C0A9649D8B63 |title=Best Sellers: Hardcover Fiction: Sunday, January 22, 2012 |date=January 22, 2012 |website=NYTimes.com (Internet Archive) |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |archivedate=November 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131127174445/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D06E7D9123EF931A15752C0A9649D8B63 }} and ''Mentats of Dune'' was released at #17 on the same list.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2014-03-30/hardcover-fiction/list.html |title=Best Sellers: Hardcover Fiction |date=March 30, 2014 |website=NYTimes.com |accessdate=April 24, 2014}} ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' called ''Sisterhood'' a "shallow but fun blend of [[space opera]] and dynastic [[soap opera]]." ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Dune franchise}} {{Kevin J. Anderson}} [[Category:Book series based on Dune| ]] [[Category:Prequel novels]] [[Category:Science fiction book series]] [[Category:Space opera novels]]

{{refimprove|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Emanuelle in America | image_size = | image = Emanuelle_in_America_DVD_Cover.jpg | caption = DVD cover | director = [[Joe D'Amato]] | producer = | screenplay = Maria Pia Fusco | story = [[Ottavio Alessi]]
[[Piero Vivarelli]] | starring = [[Laura Gemser]]
[[Gabriele Tinti (actor)|Gabriele Tinti]]
[[Roger Browne]]
[[Riccardo Salvino]]
Maria Piera Regoli
Matilde Dall'Aglio
Stefania Nocilli
[[Paola Senatore]] | music = [[Nico Fidenco]] | cinematography = [[Aristide Massaccesi]] | editing = Vincenzo Tomassi | studio = New Film Production | distributor = Fida Cinematografica | released = {{film date|1977|1|5|Italy}} | runtime = 100 minutes | country = Italy | language = Italian | budget = }} '''''Emanuelle in America''''' is a 1977 Italian [[sexploitation film]], the third in a series starring [[Laura Gemser]],{{cite web|work=[[DVD Talk]]|title=Emanuelle In America|first=by G. Noel|last=Gross|date=July 13, 2003|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/6895/emanuelle-in-america/}} made to cash in on the success of the [[France|French]] film ''[[Emmanuelle (film)|Emmanuelle]]'' (1974) and its sequels. It was the second in the series to be directed by [[Joe D'Amato]]. It is infamous for its "hardcore footage of unsimulated fellatio, penetration, ejaculation and unconventional horse husbandry". ==Plot == The fearless American journalist and fashion photographer Emanuelle travels throughout the world in search of a good story for her editor. Emanuelle is actually a globe-trotting reporter who is not afraid to disrobe in the name of investigative journalism. On her journey, she goes to Europe looking to investigate the private [[harem]] of a wealthy tycoon, Eric Van Darren where she watches a naked woman masturbate a horse named Pedro before having a sapphic encounter in a steam room. There she meets an Italian Duke, Alfredo Elvize and travels to his house in Venice where she ends up in a threesome with him and his wife before taking part in an orgy at a party they throw. She likes to see for herself what really goes on at diplomatic parties. Later, she is sent out to a private holiday resort island where women pay for men to fulfill their ultimate carnal desires. Here she sees a couple watching a disturbing [[snuff film]] and becomes determined to find out who made it. Emanuelle stumbles upon a group that uses kidnapped girls to make and sell snuff films. She has been taking several pictures with a small spy camera installed in her necklace. Eventually, she gets caught in the act and this follows with a brush with death which leaves Emanuelle wondering if it is perhaps time to hang up her camera for good. Loaded with plenty of photos with her story, on her return to New York City, she meets her editor but he refuses to print the story and the images. She feels disgusted and quits her job and goes on a long vacation with her boyfriend. ==Cast== *[[Laura Gemser]] as Emanuelle *[[Gabriele Tinti (actor)|Gabriele Tinti]] as Alfredo Elvize, Duke of Mont'Elba *[[Roger Browne]] as the Senator *[[Riccardo Salvino]] as Bill *[[Lars Bloch]] as Eric Van Darren *[[Paola Senatore]] as Laura Elvize *[[Maria Piera Regoli]] as Diana Smith *[[Lorraine De Selle]] as Gemini *[[Marina Frajese]] as the woman at the beach *[[Giulio Bianchi]] *[[Efrem Appel]] *[[Matilde Dall'Aglio]] *[[Carlo Foschi]] *[[Maria Renata Franco]] *[[Giulio Massimini]] *[[Stefania Nocilli]] == See also == * [[List of Italian films of 1977]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0074473}} * {{allrovi movie|69457}} {{Joe D'Amato}} [[Category:1977 films]] [[Category:Films directed by Joe D'Amato]] [[Category:Sexploitation films]] [[Category:Snuff films in fiction]] [[Category:Emanuelle]] [[Category:Exploitation films]] [[Category:1977 horror films]] [[Category:1970s pornographic films]] [[Category:Italian horror films]] [[Category:Italian-language films]] [[Category:Italian erotic films]] [[Category:Italian pornographic films]] [[Category:Films set in the United States]] [[Category:Splatter films]] [[Category:Zoophilia in culture]] [[Category:Italian films]] [[Category:Italian crime films]] [[Category:Films scored by Nico Fidenco]] {{erotic-film-stub}} {{1970s-Italy-film-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:April Hunter boxing.jpg|thumb|A foxy boxer — [[April Hunter]]]] '''Foxy boxing''' is a form of [[sports entertainment]] which involves two or more women [[boxing]] (or pretending to do so) in a sexualized context as a form of erotic entertainment. The participants are typically dressed in revealing clothing such as [[bikini]]s or skintight [[leotard]]s, while the actual fight usually focuses on the beauty of the combatants rather than fighting skills.<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=opYA03qIQPYC&pg=PA40 |title=Good with Their Hands |author=Carlo Rotella |publisher=University of California Press |year=2004 |isbn=978-0-520-24335-4}}</ref> Foxy boxing is unusual in that the audience generally does not care who wins. It is believed to have its roots in "singles' bars in southern California" after the interest in women's boxing began to decline in the late 1980s.<ref>{{cite book |title=International Encyclopedia of Women and Sports: A-G |last=Christensen |first=Karen |authorlink= |author2=Allen Guttmann |author3=Gertrud Pfister |year=2001 |publisher=Macmillan Reference USA |location= |isbn= |page=172 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=srYYAAAAIAAJ&q=%22foxy+boxing%22&dq=%22foxy+boxing%22&hl=en&ei=ZUztTMyWFcGAlAfzgrCNAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBzgU |accessdate=November 24, 2010}}</ref>
The mainstream competitive sport of [[women's boxing]] has tried to avoid association with foxy boxing<ref>{{cite book |title=The boxer's heart: how I fell in love with the ring |last=Sekules |first=Kate |year=2000 |publisher=Villard |page=55 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e6G1AAAAIAAJ}}</ref> but the successful female boxer [[Mia St. John]] emphasised her sexuality by appearing on the cover of [[Playboy]] magazine.<ref>{{citation |title=Women boxers: the new warriors |page=22 |year=2006 |author=C. Ondine Chavoya |isbn=978-1-55885-475-8}}</ref>
It was a popular entertainment used in the [[Philippines]] for military men in the 1980s and 90s. It included both boxing and wrestling and the women were expected to "draw blood and show bruises before they got paid".<ref>{{cite book |title=Madonnas and martyrs: militarism and violence in the Philippines |last=Hilsdon |first=Anne-Marie |authorlink= |year=1995 |publisher=Ateneo de Manila University Press |location= |isbn= |pages=99–100 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F3zDXQ-2B0kC&pg=PA99&dq=%22foxy+boxing%22&hl=en&ei=7kftTKv9A4X6lwee8YyMAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22foxy%20boxing%22&f=false |accessdate=November 24, 2010}}</ref> Foxy boxing was also utilized by bar owners in [[Thailand]] for the same type of audience.<ref>{{cite book |title=The morning after: sexual politics at the end of the Cold War |last=H. Enloe |first=Cynthia |authorlink= |year=1993 |publisher=University of California Press |location= |isbn= |page=156 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tHTECm_g6xoC&pg=PA156&dq=%22foxy+boxing%22&hl=en&ei=ZUztTMyWFcGAlAfzgrCNAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=%22foxy%20boxing%22&f=false |accessdate=November 24, 2010}}</ref>
The style of fighting was formed into a new genre by David Borden, into what came to be known as [[Kaiju Big Battel]], which was staged fights with a heavy [[tokusatsu]] and pop culture influence.<ref>{{cite journal |author= |date=October 2002 |title=Anime Instincts |journal=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]] |publisher=Bob Guccione, Jr. |volume=18 |issue=10 |pages=62 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EiUGaclNKKQC&pg=PA62&dq=%22foxy+boxing%22&hl=en&ei=507tTIuJKMWBlAft09GQAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=%22foxy%20boxing%22&f=false |doi= |pmid= |pmc= }}</ref>
Although foxy boxing is more of an entertainment spectacle than a sport, it has resulted in injuries. A foxy boxer at a high-end strip club in Rhode Island sued her employer after her silicone breast implants were ruptured in a fight. The class action suit ruled her employer liable.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
==Media and popular culture== {{Refimprove section|date=November 2010}} The sport is frequently referenced in [[popular culture]]: *Homer Simpson on ''The Simpsons'' mentioned it three times: In the season one episode "[[Homer's Night Out]],"Foxy Boxing" is one of the places where Homer and Bart stop at in their quest for [[Princess Kashmir]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The Simpsons: A Complete Guide to Our Favorite Family |last=Groening |first=Matt |year=1997 |publisher=HarperPerennial|location=New York |isbn= 0-06095252-0|page=28 }}</ref> On the season six episode "[[Lisa on Ice]]", he tells Lisa that "if the Bible has taught us nothing else--and it hasn't--it's that girls should stick to girl sports, such as hot-oil wrestling, foxy boxing, and such and such."<ref>{{cite book |title=The gospel according to the Simpsons |last=I. Pinsky |first=Mark |authorlink= |year=2007 |publisher=Westminster John Knox Press |location= |isbn= |page=122 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qlrh_eGSPZQC&pg=PA122&dq=%22foxy+boxing%22&hl=en&ei=2ErtTITvDIWKlwful9X9AQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CD0Q6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=%22foxy%20boxing%22&f=false |accessdate=November 24, 2010}}</ref> Later, on the season 12 episode "[[Tennis the Menace]]", Homer builds a tennis court, only to learn that tennis is not the same as foxy boxing (or as he calls it, "the sport where the chicks wail on each other"). *The ''[[King of the Hill]]'' episode "Boxing Luanne" centered on [[Luanne Platter]] thinking she has taken up mainstream women's boxing, only to find she has been underwritten by [[Buck Strickland]] for foxy boxing. * ''[[Miami Vice]]'' season one episode 9 "Glades" contains a scene of two women foxy boxing approximately 9 minutes into the episode. The owner of the club promoting the event even refers directly to the sport stating, "Foxy Boxing is what's in now" * In the final episode of the TV Series ''[[Freaks and Geeks]]'' (Discos & Dragons, Season 1, Ep. 18) [[Seth Rogen]]'s character Ken is thrown out of a disco club for causing a scene and making fun of disco music. As he's being escorted from the building, the bouncer at the disco club tells him not to worry too much because the disco will be shut down the following week in favor of foxy boxing.<ref name="freaks">(29 October 2010). [http://www.ifc.com/news/2010/10/discos-and-dragons.php Revived and Derived: "Freaks and Geeks" Ep. 18, "Discos and Dragons"], ''[[Independent Film Channel]]'', Retrieved November 24, 2010</ref> * On the March 17, 2010 episode of ''[[The Daily Show]]'', Jon Stewart compares the U.S. congressional debate over health care reform to foxy boxing. *In the ''[[Family Guy]]'' episode [[Baby, You Knock Me Out]] [[Lois Griffin]] starts her "boxing career" as a foxy boxer. *In Season 2, Episode 5 of ''[[30 Rock]]'', Kenneth throws a party rumored to have foxy boxing. *In ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'', [[Barney Stinson]] is a fan of foxy boxing.
==See also== {{Portal|Boxing}} * [[Catfight]] * [[Mud wrestling]] * [[Muscle worship]] *[[Bikini Basketball Association]] *[[Lingerie Basketball League]] *[[Legends Football League]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Foxy Boxing}} [[Category:Boxing]] [[Category:Sexual fetishism]] [[Category:Sports entertainment]]

'''''Game Merchant''''' was a gaming magazine first published in 1981, and was edited by Alex Marciniszyn.
==Contents== ''Game Merchant'' originated as a tabloid newspaper delivered free to game shops, but was later changed to magazine size and became available to individuals by subscription.<ref name="SG"/>
==Reception== [[Lewis Pulsipher]] reviewed ''Game Merchant'' in ''[[The Space Gamer]]'' No. 43.<ref name="SG">{{cite journal|last=Pulsipher |first=Lewis |authorlink=Lewis Pulsipher |date=September 1981 |title=Capsule Reviews|journal=[[The Space Gamer]]|publisher=[[Steve Jackson Games]]|issue=43|pages=38}}</ref> Pulsipher commented that "Without seeing the subscribers-only material I cannot say with certainty whether this publication is worth [the annual price]. However, the supplements will have to be extraordinarily long or good."<ref name="SG"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Game magazines]]

{{Infobox video game |image = Gem Smashers cover art.jpg |image_size = 250px |developer = Frame Studios |publisher = [[Metro3D, Inc.]] (GBA)
[[Crave Entertainment]] (Wii, 3DS)
Thumbstar Games (iOS)
Funbox Media (PS4, PS Vita) |released = '''Game Boy Advance'''{{vgrelease|NA|July 1, 2003{{cite web|author=Calvert, Justin |date=July 1, 2003 |title=Gem Smashers ships |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |work=[[GameSpot]] |url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/gem-smashers-ships-6030904 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130123195830/http://www.gamespot.com/news/gem-smashers-ships-6030904 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 23, 2013 |accessdate=July 1, 2009 }}}}{{vgrelease|JP|November 21, 2003{{cite web| date=October 21, 2003 | title=メトロ3D、シュールキャラクタ"うみにん"が活躍GBA用アクションパズル「パズにん～うみにんのパズルでにむ～」| url=http://game.watch.impress.co.jp/docs/20031021/metro.htm| publisher=Game Watch | language=Japanese | accessdate=April 19, 2012}}}}'''Wii/Nintendo 3DS'''
{{vgrelease|NA|November 8, 2011{{cite web |author=Downin, Jonathan |date=October 24, 2011 |title=Shippin' Out October 23–29: Battlefield 3 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/shippin-out-october-23-29-battlefield-3-6341354 |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |work=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=April 19, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201212100/http://www.gamespot.com/news/shippin-out-october-23-29-battlefield-3-6341354 |archivedate=February 1, 2012 |df= }}}}'''iOS'''{{vgrelease|WW|November 15, 2012}}'''PS4, PS Vita'''{{vgrelease|EU|February 24, 2017|NA|March 3, 2017}} |genre = [[Puzzle video game|Puzzle]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Game Boy Advance]], [[Wii]], [[Nintendo 3DS]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[PlayStation Vita]] }} '''''Gem Smashers''''', known in Japan as {{nihongo|'''''Pazuin Umininno Pazuru Denimu'''''|パズにん～うみにんのパズルでにむ～}}, is a [[puzzle video game]] developed by Frame Studios and published by [[Metro3D, Inc.]] for the [[Game Boy Advance]]. The game was released in North America on July 1, 2003, and in Japan on November 21, 2003. ''Gem Smashers'' was originally announced in 2002 under the working title "''Bau Bam Bom''", named after the three playable characters.{{cite web | author=IGN staff | date=April 4, 2002 | title=Bau Bam Bom | url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/356/356717p1.html | publisher=[[IGN]] | accessdate=April 19, 2012}} The game was ported to [[Wii]] and [[Nintendo 3DS]] on November 8, 2011. ==Reception== The game received mostly positive reviews. [[IGN]] noted that the game was "one of the most original puzzle games on the GBA so far."{{cite web|title=Gem Smashers Review|author=Tierney, Adam|date=December 3, 2003|publisher=[[IGN]]|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/442/442916p1.html|accessdate=July 1, 2009}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:2003 video games]] [[Category:Game Boy Advance games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Nintendo 3DS games]] [[Category:PlayStation Vita games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:Puzzle video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Italy]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] {{Puzzle-videogame-stub}}

<!--- please see 20180109 => https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MediaWiki_talk:Spam-whitelist/Archives/2018/01#Another_Worthy_Journal_Article_on_Wordpress ---> {{use mdy dates|date=January 2016 }} {{See also|Pornography in the United States|l1=Erotic films in the United States}} [[File:Deep Throat poster 2.jpg|thumb|right|200px|<center>The film ''[[Deep Throat (film)|Deep Throat]]'' helped inaugurate the Golden Age of Porn.</center>]]
The '''Golden Age of Porn''', or '''porno chic''', refers to a 15-year period (around 1969–1984) in [[Pornography in the United States|commercial American pornography]], which spread internationally,<ref name="WP-20070719">{{cite book |last1=Paasonen |first1=Susanna |last2=Saarenmaa |first2=Laura |title=The Golden Age of Porn: Nostalgia and History in Cinema |url=https://susannapaasonen.files.wordpress.com/2014/04/01pornification23-32.pdf |date=July 19, 2007 |format=[[PDF]] |work=[[WordPress]] |accessdate=April 30, 2017 }}</ref><ref name="Book-2015">{{cite book |editor-last1=DeLamater|editor-first1=John|editor-last2=Plante|editor-first2=Rebecca F.|editor-link1=John DeLamater |title=Handbook of the Sociology of Sexualities |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0d3yCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA416 |page=416 |date=June 19, 2015 |work=[[Springer Publishing]] |accessdate=April 30, 2017 }}</ref> in which sexually explicit films experienced positive attention from mainstream cinemas, movie critics, and the general public. It began with [[New Andy Warhol Garrick Theatre|release]] of the 1969 film ''[[Blue Movie]]'' directed by [[Andy Warhol]],<ref name="NYT-19690722">{{cite news |last=Canby |first=Vincent |authorlink=Vincent Canby |title=Movie Review – Blue Movie (1968) Screen: Andy Warhol's 'Blue Movie' |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9507E5D91738E63ABC4A51DFB1668382679EDE |date=July 22, 1969 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=December 29, 2015 }}</ref><ref name="NYT-19690810">{{cite news |last=Canby |first=Vincent |authorlink=Vincent Canby |title=Warhol's Red Hot and 'Blue' Movie. D1. Print. (behind paywall) |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9807E4D91739EF3BBC4852DFBE668382679EDE |date=August 10, 1969 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=December 29, 2015 }}</ref><ref name="WS-2002-2005">{{cite web |last=Comenas |first=Gary |title=Blue Movie (1968) |url=http://www.warholstars.org/andy-warhol-blue-movie.html |date=2005 |work=WarholStars.org |accessdate=December 29, 2015 }}</ref> and the 1970 film ''[[Mona the Virgin Nymph|Mona]]'' produced by [[Bill Osco]].<ref name="PG-20080716">{{cite web|url=http://www.pornographygirl.com/|title=Pornography|publisher=Pornography Girl|accessdate=July 16, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080506193633/http://www.pornographygirl.com/|archivedate=May 6, 2008|quote=The first explicitly pornographic film with a plot that received a general theatrical release in the U.S. is generally considered to be Mona (Mona the Virgin Nymph)...}}</ref><ref name="TM-20050329">{{cite web |last=Corliss |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard Corliss |title=That Old Feeling: When Porno Was Chic |url=http://content.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1043267,00.html |date=March 29, 2005 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=January 27, 2016 }}</ref> These films were the first [[pornographic|adult erotic films]] depicting explicit [[sex]] to receive wide theatrical release in the [[United States]].<ref name="NYT-19690722" /><ref name="NYT-19690810" /><ref name="WS-2002-2005" /><ref name="PG-20080716" /> Both influenced the making of films such as 1972's ''[[Deep Throat (film)|Deep Throat]]'' starring [[Linda Lovelace]] and directed by [[Gerard Damiano]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Sex in Cinema: 1970 Greatest and Most Influential Erotic / Sexual Films and Scenes|url=http://www.filmsite.org/sexinfilms21.html|publisher=Film Site|accessdate=January 16, 2012|page=21|quote=The storyline in the film ''Mona'' was later borrowed, to some degree, by Gerard Damiano in his film ''Deep Throat'' in 1972.}}</ref> ''[[Behind the Green Door]]'' starring [[Marilyn Chambers]] and directed by the [[Mitchell brothers]],<ref name=unknown>{{cite book|title=San Francisco: The Unknowao.uk/books?id=pXAsU1sQG1AC|isbn=1-55152-188-1|pages=238–241}}</ref> 1973's ''[[The Devil in Miss Jones]]'' also by Damiano, and 1976's ''[[The Opening of Misty Beethoven]]'' by [[Radley Metzger]].
Following mentions by [[Johnny Carson]] on his popular ''[[Tonight Show]]'' and [[Bob Hope]] on TV as well,<ref name="TM-20050329" /> ''[[Deep Throat (film)|Deep Throat]]'' achieved major box-office success, despite being rudimentary by mainstream standards. In 1973, the more accomplished, but still low-budget, film ''[[The Devil in Miss Jones]]'' was the seventh most successful film of the year, and was well received by major media, including a favorable review by film critic [[Roger Ebert]].<ref name="RE-19730613" /> The phenomenon of porn being publicly discussed by celebrities, and taken seriously by critics, a development referred to, by Ralph Blumenthal of ''[[The New York Times]]'', as "porno chic", began for the first time in modern American culture.<ref name="TM-20050329" /><ref name="NYT-19730121" /> It became obvious that box-office returns of very low-budget adult erotic films could fund further advances in the technical and production values of porn, making it extremely competitive with Hollywood films. There was concern that, left unchecked, the vast profitability of such films would lead to Hollywood being influenced by pornography.<ref name="LL-1970" /><ref name="New York Police Department 1975" />
Prior to this, thousands of U.S. state and municipal anti-obscenity laws and ordinances held that participating in the creation, distribution, or consumption of pornography constituted criminal action. Multi-jurisdictional interpretations of obscenity made such films highly susceptible to prosecution and criminal liability for obscenity, thereby greatly restricting their distribution and profit potential. However, the [[US Supreme Court]]'s 1973 decision in ''[[Miller v. California]]'', narrowing and simplifying the definition of obscenity, resulted in dramatically fewer prosecutions nationwide. Freedom in creative license, higher movie budgets and payouts, and a "Hollywood mindset", all contributed to this period.
However, with the increasing availability of [[videocassette recorder]]s for private viewing in the 1980s, video supplanted film as the preferred distribution medium for pornography, which quickly reverted to being low-budget and openly gratuitous, ending this "Golden Age".<ref name="Bad Infamy">{{cite book|last=Lehman|first=Peter|title=Bad: Infamy, Darkness, Evil, and Slime on Screen|year=2003|publisher=[[State University of New York Press]]|location=Albany, New York|isbn=978-0791459409|pages=79–88}}</ref>
==Background== Pornographic films were produced in the early 20th century as [[Stag film|"stag" movies]], intended to be viewed at male gatherings or in brothels. In the United States, social disapproval was so great that men in them sometimes attempted to conceal their face by subterfuge, such as a false mustache (used in ''[[A Free Ride]]'') or even being masked.<ref>{{cite book|last=Thompson|first=Dave|title=Black and White and Blue: Adult Cinema from the Victorian Age to the VCR|year=2007|publisher=ECW Press|isbn=9781554903023|pages=67–68|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rBP6yjQwT8QC&pg=PA67}}</ref><ref name="Thompson39">{{Harvnb|Thompson|2007|p=39.}}</ref> Very few people were ever identified as appearing in such films; and performers were often presumed to have been prostitutes or criminals. [[Vincent Drucci]] is said to have performed in a pornographic film made in 1924.<ref>http://www.myalcaponemuseum.com/id111.htm, ''My Al Capone Museum'' [http://www.myalcaponemuseum.com/id111.htm "Vincent 'The Schemer' Drucci"], Mario Gomes, accessed 14/6/14</ref> [[Candy Barr]], who appeared in the 1950s ''[[Smart Alec (1951 film)|Smart Alec]]'', was virtually unique among those appearing in stag films, having attained a degree of celebrity through her participation.<ref name="martin">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/04/arts/04barr.html?_r=0|title=Candy Barr, 70, Stripper and Star of 1950's Stag Film, Dies |last=Martin |first=Douglas |date=January 4, 2006|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=June 17, 2013}}</ref>
In the US, during the late 1960s, there was regular semi-underground production of pornographic films on a modest scale. After answering New York City newspaper advertisements for nude models, [[Eric Edwards (pornographic actor)|Eric Edwards]] and [[Jamie Gillis]], among others, appeared in these films, which were silent black and white 'loops' of low quality, often intended for peep booth viewing in the proliferation of [[adult video arcade]]s around [[Times Square]].<ref>{{cite news |authorlink=William J. Bratton |first=William J. |last= Bratton |first2=William |last2=Andrews |title=What We’ve Learned About Policing |work=[[City Journal (New York)|City Journal]] |publisher=[[Manhattan Institute for Policy Research]] |date=Spring 1999 |url=http://www.city-journal.org/html/9_2_what_weve_learned.html |accessdate=February 3, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=George L. |last=Kelling |first2=James Q. |last2=Wilson |title=Broken Windows |work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=March 1982 |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/198203/broken-windows | accessdate= February 3, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.streetdirectory.com/travel_guide/207131/new_york_guide/times_square_new_york_city.html |title=Times Square New York City |publisher=Streetdirectory.com |date= |accessdate=April 21, 2010}}</ref> The product of the New York City porn industry was distributed nationwide by underworld figure [[Robert DiBernardo]], who commissioned the production of much of the so-called 'Golden Age' era films made in New York City.<ref>{{cite book | title = What Wild Ecstasy |first=John |last=Heidenry |page=323 | publisher = [[Simon & Schuster]] | year=2002 | isbn =978-0743241847}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title= Reefer Madness: Sex, Drugs, and Cheap Labor in the American Black Market |authorlink= Eric Schlosser | first=Eric |last=Schlosser |publisher=Mariner Books |year=2004 |isbn= 978-0618446704 |page= '''???'''}}</ref> Although not the first adult film to obtain a wide theatrical release in the US, none had achieved a mass audience, and changed public attitude toward pornography, as ''[[Deep Throat (film)|Deep Throat]]'' did.
==The era== [[File:Andy Warhol by Jack Mitchell.jpg|thumb|Andy Warhol]]
=== Beginnings === ''[[Blue Movie]]'' by [[Andy Warhol]], [[New Andy Warhol Garrick Theatre|released]] in 1969,<ref name="NYT-19690722" /><ref name="NYT-19690810" /><ref name="WS-2002-2005" /> and, more freely, ''[[Mona the Virgin Nymph|Mona]]'', by [[Bill Osco]], released in 1970,<ref name="PG-20080716" /> were the first films depicting explicit [[sex]] to receive wide theatrical distribution in the [[United States]].<ref name="NYT-19690722" /><ref name="NYT-19690810" /><ref name="PG-20080716" /> Although ''Blue Movie'' involved [[sexual intercourse]], the film, starring [[Viva (actress)|Viva]] and [[Louis Waldon]], included substantial dialogue about the [[Vietnam War]] and various mundane tasks.<ref name="NYT-19690722" /><ref name="NYT-19690810" /> Besides being a seminal film in the 'Golden Age of Porn', ''Blue Movie'', according to Warhol, was a major influence in the making of ''[[Last Tango in Paris]]'' (1972), an internationally controversial erotic drama film, starring [[Marlon Brando]], and released a few years after ''Blue Movie'' was made.<ref name="WS-2002-2005" /><ref name="IMDB-BlueMovie">{{cite web |author=Staff |title=Blue Movie (1969) |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0062745 |date= |work=[[IMDB]] |accessdate=December 29, 2015 }}</ref>
The film ''Mona'' differed from ''Blue Movie'' by presenting more of a [[Plot (narrative)|story plot]]: Mona (played by Fifi Watson) had promised her mother that she would remain a virgin until her impending marriage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://picpal.com/fleshgordon/fgint3.html |title=Flesh Gordon Interview 3 |publisher=PicPal.com |accessdate=July 16, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828123431/http://picpal.com/fleshgordon/fgint3.html |archivedate=August 28, 2008 }}</ref> Later, in December 1971, the film ''[[Boys in the Sand]]'', one of the first adult erotic films, after ''Blue Movie'' in 1969,<ref name="WS-1969">{{cite web |last=Comenas |first=Gary |title=July 21, 1969: Andy Warhol's Blue Movie Opens |url=http://www.warholstars.org/andy-warhol-1969.html |date=1969 |work=WarholStars.org |accessdate=January 20, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="JW-2015">{{cite book |last=Haggerty |first=George E. |title=A Companion to Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer Studies |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eUf3CQAAQBAJ&pg=PA339&lpg=PA339&dq=Variety+June+18,+1969+%22Blue+Movie%22&source=bl&ots=fce9PuITMk&sig=YSS9R0fpvprgjHJMeFvp8VxiLoU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwinxffWnbnKAhWIrD4KHZIRAUcQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=Variety%20June%2018%2C%201969%20%22Blue%20Movie%22&f=false |date=2015 |work=[[John Wiley & Sons]] |page=339 |accessdate=January 20, 2016 }}</ref> to be reviewed by ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' magazine,<ref>Stevenson p. 113</ref> was [[55th Street Playhouse|released]] and opened in theaters across the United States and around the world.<ref>Rutledge (1989) p. 63</ref> The film's title is a [[Parody film|parodic]] reference to the [[The Boys in the Band (play)|1968 play]] by [[Mart Crowley]], and the related [[Derivative work|1970 film adaptation]], ''[[The Boys in the Band]]''.<ref name = Halter>{{cite news |last=Halter |first=Ed |title=Return to Paradise |work=[[Village Voice]] |pages = |publisher= |date=June 18, 2002 |url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2002/06/18/return-to-paradise/ |accessdate=November 10, 2017}}</ref>
===''Deep Throat''=== The 'Golden Age of Porn' continued in 1972 with ''[[Deep Throat (film)|Deep Throat]]''. It officially premiered at the World Theater<ref>[http://cinematreasures.org/theater/2664/ World Theater] at CinemaTreasures.org</ref> in New York City on June 12, 1972 and was advertised in ''[[The New York Times]]'' under the [[bowdlerized]] title ''Throat''. After [[Johnny Carson]] talked about the film on his nationally top-rated TV show<ref name="NYT-19730121" /><ref name="Hollywood v. Hard Core">{{cite book|last=Lewis|first=Jon|title=Hollywood v. Hard Core: How the Struggle Over Censorship Created the Modern Film Industry|year=2000|publisher=[[New York University Press]]|location=New York, New York|isbn=978-0814751428|pages=260–67}}</ref><ref>Chuck Traynor, speaking in the documentary ''Inside Deep Throat'' (2005)</ref><ref name=Hardcore>{{cite book|title=Hard core: power, pleasure, and the "frenzy of the visible"|publisher=[[University of California Press]]|author=[[Linda Williams (film critic)|Williams, Linda]] |year=1999|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3wAe48_yfNUC|isbn=0-520-21943-0|pages=156–158}}</ref><ref name=Kelly>{{cite book|title=Handbook of organized crime in the United States|publisher=[[Greenwood Publishing Group]]|author1=Robert J. Kelly |author2=Ko-lin Chin |author3=Rufus Schatzberg |year=1994|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CWg1Efv5C5UC|isbn=0-313-28366-4|pages=301–302}}</ref> and [[Bob Hope]], as well, mentioned it on TV,<ref name="TM-20050329" /> ''Deep Throat'' became very profitable and a box-office success, according to one of the figures behind the film. In its second year of release, ''Deep Throat'' just missed ''Variety's'' top 10. However, by then, it was often being shown in a double bill with the most successful of the top three adult erotic films released in the 1972–1973 era, ''[[The Devil in Miss Jones]]'', which easily outperformed ''Deep Throat'', while leaving ''[[Behind the Green Door]]'' trailing in third place.<ref name=lewis211-212>Lewis, p.211-212</ref>
===''The Devil in Miss Jones''=== The 1973 film ''[[The Devil in Miss Jones]]'' was ranked number seven in the ''Variety '' list of the top ten highest-grossing pictures of 1973, despite lacking the wide release and professional marketing of Hollywood and having been virtually banned across the country for half the year (see Miller v. California, below).<ref name=lewis211-212 /> Some critics have described the film as, along with ''Deep Throat'', one of the "two best erotic motion pictures ever made".<ref>{{cite book|title=Offensive literature: decensorship in Britain, 1960–1982|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|author=Sutherland, John |year=1983|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=udkN4xWi2r0C|isbn=0-389-20354-8|page=136}}</ref> [[William Friedkin]] called ''[[The Devil in Miss Jones]]'' a "great film", partly because it was one of the few adult erotic films with a proper storyline.<ref>{{cite book|title=The erotic thriller in contemporary cinema|publisher=Indiana University Press|author=Williams, Linda Ruth |year=2005|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QOiY931rxDEC|isbn=0-253-34713-0|page=134}}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]] referred to ''The Devil in Miss Jones'' as the "best" of the genre he had seen and gave it three-stars (of four).<ref name="RE-19730613">{{cite web |last=Ebert |first=Roger |authorlink=Roger Ebert |title=The Devil In Miss Jones – Film Review |url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/the-devil-in-miss-jones-1973 |date=June 13, 1973 |publisher=[[RogerEbert.com]] |accessdate=February 7, 2015 }}</ref> Ebert also suggested the film's box office receipts were inflated as a way of [[money laundering|laundering]] the profits from illegal activities, although such a method would have required organised crime to be paying taxes on their illegally obtained income.<ref name="CST-20050211">{{cite news |last=Ebert |first=Roger |authorlink=Roger Ebert |title=Inside Deep Throat |url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/inside-deep-throat-2005 |date=February 11, 2005 |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |accessdate=February 8, 2016 }}</ref><ref>Reefer Madness: Sex, Drugs, and Cheap Labor in the American Black Market, Eric Schlosser, p144</ref>
''The Devil in Miss Jones'' was one of the first films to be inducted into the [[XRCO Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dirtybob.com/xrco/hall.htm |title=Hall of Fame |publisher=Dirty Bob/X-Rated Critics Organization |accessdate=June 15, 2015}}</ref> The sound-recording, cinematography, and story-line of ''The Devil in Miss Jones'' were of a considerably higher quality than any previous porn film. The lead, [[Georgina Spelvin]], who had been in the original Broadway run of ''[[The Pajama Game]]'', combined vigorous sex with an acting performance some thought as convincing as anything to be seen in a good mainstream production. She had been hired as a caterer, but [[Gerard Damiano]], the film director, was impressed with her reading of Miss Jones's dialogue, while auditioning an actor for the non-sex role of 'Abaca'. According to ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'s '' review, "With ''The Devil in Miss Jones'', the hard-core porno feature approaches an art form, one that critics may have a tough time ignoring in the future". The review also described the plot as comparable to [[Jean-Paul Sartre]]'s play ''[[No Exit]]'',<ref name=Lewis11>Lewis, p.211</ref> and went on to describe the opening scene as, "a sequence so effective it would stand out in any legit theatrical feature."<ref name=Lewis11/> It finished by stating, "Booking a film of this technical quality into a standard sex house is tantamount to throwing it on the trash heap of most current hard-core fare." <ref name="Hollywood v. Hard Core" /><ref name=Lewis11/><ref name="Porn Chic">{{cite web|title=History of Sex in Cinema: Porn Chic of the 1970s|url=http://www.filmsite.org/sexinfilms23a.html|publisher=AMC Filmsite ([[AMC Networks]]) | first= Tim | last= Dirks | date= n.d. | accessdate=September 12, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The encyclopedia of guilty pleasures: 1001 things you hate to love|publisher=[[Quirk Books]]|author1=Sam Stall |author2=Lou Harry |author3=Julia Spalding |year=2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LqaOE25UiMsC|isbn=1-931686-54-8|page=182}}</ref><ref name=Pennington>{{cite book|title=The history of sex in American film|publisher=[[Greenwood Publishing Group]]|author=Pennington, Jody W. |year=2007|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OfAKgZ68a9AC|isbn=0-275-99226-8|page=56}}</ref><ref name=Olson>{{cite book |title=Historical dictionary of the 1970s |publisher=[[Greenwood Publishing Group]] |author=Olson, James Stuart |year=1999 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YKkF8vQRcp0C |isbn=0-313-30543-9 |page=125}}</ref><ref name=spelvin>{{cite book |title =The Devil Made Me Do It |publisher=Georginas World |year= 2008 |authorlink=Georgina Spelvin |first=Georgina |last=Spelvin | isbn = 978-0615199078 | page= '''??'''}}</ref><ref>SF blogs, David-Elijah Nahmod Thu., October 10, 2013 [http://blogs.sfweekly.com/exhibitionist/2013/10/porn_star_georgina_spelvin.php Forty Years After The Devil in Miss Jones: Georgina Spelvin's Happy Ending]</ref>
==="Porno chic"=== {{See also|Pornographication}} An influential five-page article in ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]'' in 1973 described the phenomenon of porn being publicly discussed by celebrities, and taken seriously by critics, a development referred to, by Ralph Blumenthal of ''[[The New York Times]]'', as "porno chic".<ref name="TM-20050329" /><ref name="NYT-19730121">{{cite news |last=Blumenthal |first=Ralph |title=Porno chic; 'Hard-core' grows fashionable-and very profitable |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1973/01/21/archives/pornochic-hardcore-grows-fashionableand-very-profitable.html |date=January 21, 1973 |work=[[The New York Times Magazine]] |accessdate=January 20, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Jan Willem | first = Geerinck | title = Porno Chic (blog) | url = http://www.jahsonic.com/PornoChic.html | website = jahsonic.com }}</ref> Some expressed the opinion that pornographic films would continue to extend their access to US theaters, and the [[Mainstream#In film|mainstream film industry]] would gravitate toward the influence of porn.<ref name="LL-1970">From a 1970s interview with Linda Lovelace, shown in the documentary ''[[Inside Deep Throat]]''.</ref><ref name="New York Police Department 1975">{{cite news | title = Mafia Money Infiltrates Pornos Movie Business | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1873&dat=19751012&id=uIcpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ctEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=828,4533369&hl=en | work = [[Daytona Beach Morning Journal]] | date = October 12, 1975 | access-date = September 5, 2016 | quote = "If the trend continues, these people are going to become a major force in the movie industry within a few years," said Capt. Lawrence Hepburn of the New York Police Department's organized crime division. "The movie business is going to be like the garment business, riddled with Mafia influence." }}</ref>
===Supreme Court's 1973 ''Miller v. California''=== Supreme Court's 1973 ''[[Miller v. California]]'' decision redefined obscenity from "utterly without socially redeeming value" to lacks "serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value". Crucially, it made 'contemporary community standards' the criterion, holding that obscenity was not protected by the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]]; the ruling gave leeway to local judges to seize and destroy prints of films adjudged to violate local community standards. The Miller decision stymied porn distribution.<ref name="Hollywood v. Hard Core" /> ''[[The Devil in Miss Jones]]'', as well as ''[[Deep Throat (film)|Deep Throat]]'' and ''[[Behind the Green Door]]'', was prosecuted successfully during the latter half of 1973; the Supreme Court's Miller decision closed much of America to the exhibition of adult erotic films, and often led to it being banned outright. Porn films would never again feature so prominently in the mainstream movie business,<ref name="Encyclopedia of Censorship">{{cite book|last=Green|first=Jonathon & Nicholas J. Karolides|title=Encyclopedia of Censorship|year=2005|publisher=Facts on File|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-0816044641|page=44}}</ref> until the emergence of the [[internet]] in the 1990s.<ref name=2014Mainstreaming>{{cite web|last1=Tongue|first1=Stewart|title=Crowdsourcing Column: Mainstream vs. Adult|url=http://business.avn.com/articles/technology/Crowdsourcing-Column-Mainstream-vs-Adult-553023.html|website=AVN.com|publisher=Adult Video News|accessdate=July 24, 2014}}</ref>
===Post-1973=== In the aftermath of the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]]'s decision to have put mass box office returns beyond the reach of pornographic films, the leaps in the films' quality that had occurred between 1972 and 1973 were not sustained. With their relatively modest financial means, a predicted move of organized crime into Hollywood failed to materialize.<ref name="New York Police Department 1975"/> Pornographic films continued to be a highly profitable business, and thrived throughout the rest of the 1970s, leading to the concept of porn "stars" gaining currency. Ostracism of porn performers meant they almost invariably used pseudonyms. Being outed as having appeared in porn usually put an end to an actor's hope of a mainstream career.<ref name=Nitke>[[Barbara Nitke|Nitke Barbara]], in {{cite web |url=http://atomiclegdropzine.wordpress.com/2014/02/04/american-ecstasy-the-photography-of-barbara-nitke-and-the-golden-age-of-pornography/ |title=American Ecstasy: The Photography of Barbara Nitke and The Golden Age of Pornography |date=February 4, 2014 |publisher=AtomicLegdropZine.wordpress.com/ |accessdate=June 13, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527071231/http://atomiclegdropzine.wordpress.com/2014/02/04/american-ecstasy-the-photography-of-barbara-nitke-and-the-golden-age-of-pornography/ |archivedate=May 27, 2014 |df=mdy }}</ref> An indication of the returns still possible was that a 1976 release, ''[[Alice in Wonderland (1976 film)|Alice in Wonderland: An X-Rated Musical Comedy]]'', favorably reviewed by film critic [[Roger Ebert]] in 1976,<ref name="RE-19761124">{{cite web |last=Ebert |first=Roger |authorlink=Roger Ebert |title=Alice in Wonderland:An X-Rated Musical Fantasy |url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/alice-in-wonderland-1976 |date=November 24, 1976 |publisher=[[RogerEbert.com]] |accessdate=February 26, 2016 }}</ref> reportedly grossed over $90 million globally.<ref name="Hollywood v. Hard Core" /><ref name="Alice Beyond Wonderland">{{cite book|last=Hollingsworth|first=Cristopher|title=Alice Beyond Wonderland: Essays for the Twenty-first Century|year=2009|publisher=University Of Iowa Press|location=Iowa City, IA|isbn=978-1587298196|page=182}}</ref> Some historians assess ''[[The Opening of Misty Beethoven]]'', based on the play ''[[Pygmalion (play)|Pygmalion]]'' by [[George Bernard Shaw]] (and its derivative, ''[[My Fair Lady (film)|My Fair Lady]]''), and directed by [[Radley Metzger]], as attaining a [https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Cult_Film_Reader.html?id=dWX4AAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=kp_read_button#v=snippet&q=Metzger&f=false mainstream level in storyline and sets].<ref>{{cite book |last=Mathijs |first=Ernest |last2=Mendik |first2=Xavier |title=The Cult Film Reader |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWX4AAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=978-0335219230+%22The+Cult+Film+Reader%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj-6efqoebeAhUN1lkKHVltCnkQ6AEIMDAB#v=onepage&q=978-0335219230%20%22The%20Cult%20Film%20Reader%22&f=false |publisher=[[Open University Press]] |year=2007 |isbn=978-0335219230|page=}}</ref> Author [[Toni Bentley]] called the film the "crown jewel" of the Golden Age.<ref name="PB-201406">{{cite web |last=Bentley |first=Toni |authorlink=Toni Bentley |title=The Legend of Henry Paris |url=http://www.playboy.com/articles/the-legend-of-henry-paris |date=June 2014 |work=[[Playboy (magazine)|Playboy]] |accessdate=January 26, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="TB-201406">{{cite web |last=Bentley |first=Toni |authorlink=Toni Bentley |title=The Legend of Henry Paris |url=http://www.tonibentley.com/pdfarticles/playboy/RadleyMetzger_AuteuroftheErotic_ToniBentley.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |date=June 2014 |work=[[Playboy (magazine)|Playboy]] |accessdate=January 26, 2016 }}</ref>
In general, after 1973, adult erotic films emulated mainstream filmmaking storylines and conventions, merely to frame the depictions of sexual activity to prepare an 'artistic merit' defense against possible obscenity charges. The adult film industry remained stuck at the level of 'one day wonders', finished by participants hired for only a single day. The ponderous technology of the time meant filming a simple scene would often take hours due to the need for the camera to be laboriously set up for each shot.<ref name=brennan>{{cite web |url=http://susannahbreslin.net/blog/2013/11/21/cx246pc0b0u1ooo36fyytpnrt4hv78 |title=From Sexploitation Star to Porn Star: An Interview with Colleen Brennan | authorlink=Susannah Breslin |first=Susannah |last=Breslin |publisher=Susannah Breslin official site |date=November 25, 2013 |accessdate=June 13, 2014}}</ref> Repeated sustained performances might be required on cue at any time over the course of a day, which was an issue for men without the recourse to modern [[Viagra]]-type drugs.<ref name=Nitke /><ref name=brennan /> Production was concentrated in New York City where organized crime was widely believed to have control over all aspects of the business, and to prevent entry of competitors. Although their budgets were usually very low, a subcultural level of appreciation exists for films of this era, which were produced by a core group of around thirty performers, some of whom had other jobs. Several were actors who could handle dialogue when required. However, some participants scoffed at the idea that what they did, qualified as "acting".<ref name="TM-20050329" /><ref name="Hollywood v. Hard Core" /><ref name=Nitke /> By the early 1980s, the rise of home video had led to the end of the era when people went to movie theaters to see sex shot on 35mm film with production values, ultimately culminating with the rise of the internet in the 1990s and beyond.<ref name=Nitke />
==Feminist criticism== {{further information|Feminist views of pornography}} The 'Golden Age' was a period of interactions between pornography and the contemporaneous [[second-wave feminism|second wave of feminism]]. [[Radical feminists|Radical]] and [[cultural feminism|cultural feminists]], along with [[religious]] and [[conservative]] groups, attacked pornography,<ref name="GLBTQ-2004">{{cite journal |last=Chenier |first=Elise |title=Lesbian Sex Wars |url=http://www.glbtqarchive.com/ssh/lesbian_sex_wars_S.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |date=2004 |journal=GLBTQ Journal |pages=1–3 |accessdate=December 30, 2015 }}</ref><ref name="InOurTime-p360">{{cite book |last=Brownmiller |first=Susan |title=In Our Time: Memoir of a Revolution |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/In_Our_Time.html?id=oMohu95EEFMC |date=1999 |work=[[Dial Press]] |page=360 |ISBN=0-385-31486-8 |accessdate=December 30, 2015 }}</ref> while other feminists were pro-pornography, such as [[Camille Paglia]], who defined what came to be known as [[sex-positive feminism]] in her work, ''[[Sexual Personae]]''. Paglia and other sex-positive or pro-pornography feminists accepted porn as part of the [[sexual revolution]] with its [[libertarianism|libertarian]] sexual themes, such as exploring [[bisexuality]] and [[Swinging (sexual practice)|swinging]], free from government interference. The endorsement of female critics was essential for the credibility of the brief era of "porno chic".<ref name=Glass>{{cite journal|title=Bad Sex: Second Wave Feminism and Porn’s Golden Age. |url=http://search.proquest.com/openview/40b50274e13643f23165423cb36337ca/1 |journal=[[Radical Society]]|date=October 2002|first=Loren|last=Glass|volume=29|issue=3|pages=55–66}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Bailey |first=Cameron |title=Blow-by-blow accounts |work=NOW Toronto |date=February 2005 |volume=24 |number=24 |url=http://www.nowtoronto.com/movies/story.cfm?content=145887&archive=24,24,2005 |accessdate=2008-03-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928090629/http://www.nowtoronto.com/movies/story.cfm?content=145887&archive=24,24,2005 |archivedate=September 28, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref><ref>Weitzer p. 52</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Porn studies|publisher=[[Duke University Press]]|author=Williams, Linda |year=2004 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rdWZ8JD5dkkC |isbn=0-8223-3312-0 |page=320}}</ref>
==Golden Age stars== Major [[pornographic film actor]]s of the first part of the 'Golden Age', the "porno chic" era, included: {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Rene Bond]] * [[Rick Cassidy]] * [[Marilyn Chambers]] * [[Casey Donovan (actor)|Casey Donovan]] * [[Eric Edwards (actor)|Eric Edwards]] * [[Samantha Fox (actress)|Samantha Fox]] * [[Jamie Gillis]] * [[Annette Haven]] * [[John Holmes (actor)|John C. Holmes]] (a.k.a. "Johnny Wadd") * [[Mike Horner (actor)|Mike Horner]] * [[Robert Kerman]] (a.k.a. "R Bolla") * [[Johnnie Keyes|Johnny Keyes]] * [[Gloria Leonard]] * [[John Leslie (director)|John Leslie]] * [[Linda Lovelace]] * [[William Margold]] * [[Kay Parker]] * [[George Payne (actor)|George Payne]] * [[Rhonda Jo Petty]] * [[Harry Reems]] * [[Vanessa del Rio]] * [[Candida Royalle]] * [[Herschel Savage]] * [[Joey Silvera]] * [[Georgina Spelvin]] * [[Annie Sprinkle]] * [[Marc Stevens (actor)|Marc Stevens]] * [[Jessie St. James]] * [[Paul Thomas (director)|Paul Thomas]] * [[Jennifer Welles]] * [[Marlene Willoughby]] }}

"Aunt Peg") * [[Erica Boyer]] * [[Colleen Brennan]] * [[Jerry Butler (actor)|Jerry Butler]] * [[Tom Byron]] * [[Christy Canyon]] * [[Desireé Cousteau]] * [[Barbara Dare]] * [[Billy Dee]] * [[Lisa De Leeuw]] * [[Debi Diamond]] * [[Jeanna Fine]] * [[Veronica Hart]] * [[Nina Hartley]] * [[Ryan Idol]] * [[Ron Jeremy]] * [[Keisha (actress)|Keisha]] * [[Angel Kelly]] * [[Hyapatia Lee]] * [[Traci Lords]] * [[Amber Lynn]] * [[Ginger Lynn]] * [[Porsche Lynn]] * [[Shanna McCullough]] * [[Sharon Mitchell]] * [[Kelly Nichols]] * [[Peter North (actor)|Peter North]] * [[Seka]] * [[Long Dong Silver]] * [[Samantha Strong]] * [[Karen Summer]] * [[Lysa Thatcher]] * [[Randy West (actor)|Randy West]] * [[Bambi Woods]] * [[Jack Wrangler]] * [[Ona Zee]] }}
At the time of the maturation of the second wave, movies increasingly were being shot on video for home release.
As their popularity rose, so did their control of their careers. John Holmes became the first recurring porn character in the "Johnny Wadd" film series directed by [[Bob Chinn (film director)|Bob Chinn]]. Lisa De Leeuw was one of the first to sign an exclusive contract with a major adult production company, [[Vivid Video]], and Marilyn Chambers worked in mainstream movies, being one of the first of a rare number of crossover porn actors.

"Henry Paris")]] * [[Mitchell Brothers]] ([[Artie Mitchell|Artie]] and [[Mitchell brothers|Jim]]) * [[Bill Osco]] * [[Chuck Vincent (director)|Chuck Vincent]] * [[Andy Warhol]] {{div col end}}

{{short description|1930 animated film}} {{italic title}} <!-- Infoboxes are optional, please gain consesus on the talk page before adding one. Thanks.--> [[File:Title card of Good Old Schooldays (1930).png|thumb|289x289px|The title card for ''Good Old Schooldays''.]] '''''Good Old Schooldays''''' is a 1930 American film produced by [[The Van Beuren Corporation]] and released by [[Pathé|Pathe]].<ref name=":0">{{Citation|last=krazykat1977|title=Aesop's Fables - Good Old Schooldays|date=2012-04-11|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RnSZjByCySA|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref> The film, which features Milton and Rita Mouse, was directed by [[John Foster (cartoonist)|John Foster]] and Mannie Davis.<ref name=":0" />
Released on March 7, 1930,<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=M7vwCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA287&lpg=PA287&dq=good+old+schooldays+aesop&source=bl&ots=WPyyi601kq&sig=o9iWfhEb0C4My7n8_r0BXqIuiN8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi2kKmo3tjbAhXCDcAKHRB9BpAQ6AEISTAI#v=onepage&q=good%20old%20schooldays%20aesop&f=false|title=The First Hollywood Sound Shorts, 1926–1931|last=Bradley|first=Edwin M.|date=2009-04-27|publisher=McFarland|isbn=9781476606842|language=en}}</ref> the film takes place inside of a schoolhouse, and is part of a series entitled [[Aesop's Sound Fables|''Aesop's Sound Fables'']], though its plot has no relation to the fables.
==Characters== As with many of the Aesop Sound Fables at that time, this cartoon featured both Milton and Rita Mouse.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> There are also other characters, like goats, dogs, and mice.<ref name=":0" />
==Plot== [[File:The school dancing, from Good Old Schooldays (1930).png|thumb|289x289px|The school dancing.]] The film starts with many species of animals traveling to school. The teacher rings a bell to signal the start of lessons. In response of the bell, the teacher is flung about by the excited students entering the school. The children to sing "[[My Country, 'Tis of Thee]]", which was a ''[[de facto]]'' anthem for America at that time. After the singing, an animal gives the teacher an [[apple]], before taking it back and eating it when the teacher wasn't looking. Rita then plays a [[piano]], and Milton sings a [[song]]. However, he forgets the words and begins to sing phrases of nonsense. After the performance, the teacher asks a mouse (named Willie Jones) in the class if he has written his composition yet. Jones says no, but he can whistle "the theme song". He then brings out a [[flute]] and starts to play. The other animals join in, using both themselves and various items as instruments. These include a goat using his [[dunce cap]] as a trumpet, the elephant using his trunk as a [[trombone]], and several duck's using their beaks as a [[xylophone]]. Due to the music, the schoolhouse comically dances. As a result of the dancing, the building collapses and all the animals run out of it.<ref name=":0" />
The film ends with a moral, which is unrelated to the preceding film and portrayed as a cartoon featuring a man and a girl. The man states that "A Powdered Nose is No Guarantee of a Clean Neck." This angers the lady, who trips him up with her foot and hits him in the head with her [[Handbag|purse]].<ref name=":0" />
== Reception == ''Good Old Schooldays'' received mixed reviews in the cinema review magazines at that time.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/motionpic41moti|title=Motion Picture News (Jan - Mar 1930)|last=Motion Picture News|first=|date=1930|publisher=New York, Motion Picture News|others=New York The Museum of Modern Art Library|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/filmdailyvolume55152newy|title=The Film Daily (Jan-Jun 1930)|last=New York|first=Wid's Films and Film Folk|date=1930|publisher=New York, Wid's Films and Film Folks, Inc.|others=Media History Digital Library|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> The cartoon was featured as <nowiki>''Okay''</nowiki> by the ''[[Motion Picture News]]''.<ref name=":2" /> The magazine said that whilst "This release has sufficient merriment to tickle the sides of the crabbish", the magazine criticised the lack of amusing gags and the magazine's closing note for the cartoon was that it was "Okay for a heavy feature".<ref name=":2" /> The cartoon was viewed more favorable by [[The Film Daily|''The Film Daily'']],<ref name=":3" /> who said the film was a "highly amusing filler".<ref name=":3" />
== External links == {{IMDb title|id=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0161625/|title=Good Old Schooldays}}
{{YouTube|id=RnSZjByCySA|title=''Good Old Schooldays''}}
== References == <references />
